post.title: Hate AAA Games-As-A-Service? Follow Indie Gaming Instead

div.p: Every time I see one of these complaints about AAA games-as-a-service and how much better things used to be in the old days, I always wonder- have you not been paying attention to the indie gaming sphere? I prefer the state of modern gaming compared to the 90s just for indie games.

For one thing, there's a lot of them now, with a bewildering diversity of genre and implementation. The kinds of games that would have maybe one release every two years, like Bioware-style RPGs or metroidvanias or space-fighter sims, often have multiple titles a year. And they aren't usually identical, but vary wildly. Look at just metroidvanias - want insect-themed Victorian steampunk? Done. Craving BDSM Catholicism instead? Done. How about Mexican Wrestling themed? Done! This massive amount of choice wasn't available 20 years ago. (Plus, you can still play a lot of the games that came out back then!)

And while AAA games are pretty creatively sterile and derivative, there are some wonderfully imaginative and downright weird games that have come out this decade. Like one where you play as an archaeologist deciphering a forgotten language. Or a surgeon in a Russian steppe using mysticism to cure a plague. Or the quasi-turn-based game where you use a talking sword to fight the Illuminati in a computer simulation. If you're bored by the sameness of the big games, take a gander at the small ones. You never know what you might find.
(If you just a first-person shooter or a decent puzzle game, there's that too.)
And many of these games (including every single one I linked to) are available on gog.com, DRM-free! No "games as a service" - you buy it, you own it.

So, yeah, the big releases by the big companies are kinda shit and the practices they want to normalize are questionably moral. But I don't understand pining for the good old days and condemning the games industry as a whole when there's still a bunch of stuff going on unrelated to the mainstream AAA sphere.
